properties.name: Grazer Burg
properties.description-translated: The Graz castle is located in the east of the old town of Graz, near the Graz Cathedral, and was built from 1438 by Duke Friedrich V, later Roman-German Emperor Friedrich III. Due to the low defense value, the castle was connected to the fortress on Schloßberg via a hidden gait. From 1564 Graz was the capital inner Austria and the castle became the seat of the Inner -Austrian Archduke. Because of this position, it was rebuilt and enlarged. After Archduke Ferdinand II was crowned the emperor in 1619 and moved to Vienna, the castle lost its function as the seat of the sovereign and was neglected.

properties.name: Burg Neulengbach
properties.description-translated: The Neulengbach Castle was a high-altitude castle on a free-standing and around 80 m high mountain cone above the Lower Austrian city of Neulengbach in the Sankt Pölten-Land district, which was converted into a castle in the 16th and 17th centuries. The castle facility is a three -storey multi -corner building with a double weir ring and eight round towers, an stem with a magnificent Renaissance portal and a farm with Tuscan double pillars and stone fountain pools.

Neuberg Castle is a Styrian Höhenburg, whose medieval builders were included in a modern fortress.

properties.name: Burg Kreuzenstein

properties.name: Burgruine Twimberg
properties.description-translated: The Burgruine Twimberg is the ruin of a high castle over the town of Twimberg in the municipality of Bad St. Leonhard. The former Zwingburg was built in the mastery of the Waldenstein trench at the talent of the Waldensteiner into the narrow Lavanttal.

properties.name: Burg Plankenstein
properties.description-translated: Burg Plankenstein is located in the Plankenstein of the same name, about 4 kilometers southwest of Texing in Lower Austria. The Höhenburg was first mentioned in 1186 and was built by the Plankensteiners, feudal people of the Counts of Peilstein. The family name is derived from the word blanc (= white) and means that from the white stone.

properties.name: Burg Heinfels
properties.description-translated: Heinfels Castle is an extensive high castle area above Heinfels in East Tyrol. The strategically well -located military system at 1130 m above sea level. A. represents a striking landmark of the eastern Puster Valley. From the castle you have a long view of the draust and downwards and the Tyrolean Gailtal opposite.

properties.name: Burgruine Gomarn
properties.description-translated: The extensive building system of the Gomarn castle ruin is located on the back of a hill near Bad St. Leonhard in the Lavanttal.

properties.name: Schloss Purgstall
properties.description-translated: Purgstall Castle is a listed [1] palace complex in the Lower Austrian market town of Purgstall an der Erlauf. It is located in the northern part of the core on an approximately triangular plateau from conglomerate at the mouth of the Feichsenbach and is probably the most important facility in the river valley [2]. The heterogeneous architecture of the ensemble illustrates very well, as the system from the 13th century was continued and enlarged by its respective owners. The castle is privately owned and cannot be visited, only part of the castle park is accessible to the public.

properties.name: Ruine Stauff
properties.description-translated: The Stauf castle ruins is the ruin of a high castle in the Upper Austrian municipality of Haibach OB of the Danube in the Eferding district. The medieval facility was probably founded in the 12th century by Wernhard de Stove, an ancestor of the Counts of Schaunberg, and developed from a highly noble center of rule to an administrative headquarters, which was taken over by various nurses. The castle was built as a family headquarters before the Schaunberger moved its headquarters to Schaunberg Castle, so that Stauf was from then on only a side castle of the family. [1]

properties.name: Burg Oberkapfenberg

properties.name: Alte Burg

properties.name: Burgruine Klingenstein
properties.description-translated: The ruins of the Klingenstein Castle, also as Castle Salla and in the literature, partly known under the double name "Burg Klingenstein/Salla", is located west of the village of Salla in the market town of Maria Lankowitz in West Styria. The [1] Burg, first called Klingenstein in 1834, was built into the upper Murtal to protect the Voitsberg trading road via the Gaberl. Its history can only be reconstructed in a incomplete manner due to the lack of written sources. Due to structural details, such as the masonry and the design of the shooting range, a construction in the second half of the 15th century seems likely to be likely, which is quite late compared to other Austrian castles. The counts of Montfort are suitable as builders, which at that time held the rule over the nearby village of Salla. From the 16th century at the latest, the castle was owned by the Saurau nobility family and subsequently the Glojacher. The castle was probably destroyed by a fire in the 16th century and was not rebuilt. From 1982/1983, the ruin was rebuilt by the former mayor of the former municipality of Salla, whereby these structures were partially new buildings and were definitely controversial among researchers. So far, three archaeological excavations have also taken place, which did not include the entire Burg area.

properties.name: Burg Piberstein

The Felsenburg was built in the 13th century, expanded around 1620 and fell into the ruin over time. It has been renovated since 1964 and is now used as a regional cultural center.

properties.name: Burg Pürnstein

The castle is a former water castle, one of the few in Carinthia. Today Frauenstein is privately owned.

properties.name: Ruine Krems

properties.description-translated: The Krems castle ruin is located east of the municipality of Voitsberg in Styria in the Krems district. The history of the castle goes back to the 11th or 12th centuries when it had the Salzburg archbishop built. In 1248 it was first mentioned in a document. Krems was in possession of larger nobility families several times, but most of whom have commissioned nurses or administrators with the administration of the rule. In the 14th century, Krems was the lower jurisdiction and in the 16th century the castle was expanded into a Renaissance castle with zoo. In the 17th century, Count Karl Saurau bought the property and put it together with his rule Ligist. After moving the administration to the Ligist Castle in 1730, he neglected Krems and left it to decay. In 1817, part of the castle slipped after a rain shower. In 1857 it bought Archduke Johann.

After the collapse of a part of the inner ring wall, noticed on December 27, 2020, the path to and around the ruin was officially closed. [2]

properties.name: Festung Hohensalzburg
properties.description-translated: The Hohensalzburg fortress is the landmark of the city of Salzburg. It is located on a mountain above the city, the fortress mountain, which continues to the northwest in the Mönchsberg. The foothills in the east of the fortress mountain is called Nonnberg, on which the Benedictine women-to-women female nonnberg is located directly below the eastern outdoor facilities of the fortress. The Hohensalzburg Fortress is one of the largest castle complexes in Europe with over 7,000 m² of built -up area (including the bastals over 14,000 m²), which goes back to the 11th century. As one of the largest fully preserved castles in Central Europe, it has over a million visitors every year and is therefore the most popular attraction in Austria outside of Vienna, whereby it is also only exceeded in the federal capital of Schönbrunn and the art historical museum (visitor statistics 2017). [1]

properties.name: Burg Seebenstein

In the latter there is an important collection of weapons and medieval art, including a veit shock. A Madonna by Tilman Riemenschneider was sold (before 2004). There is a chapel in a corner of the high lock.
